questions.text: What is the minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
The minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome is 3.5 g/day. 

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body and frothy urine. Urinary examination revealed grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. There were no red blood cells in the urine. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?

choices.text: IgA nephropathy is the likely diagnosis.
It is associated with low C3 levels.
No IgG  or C3 deposition is seen on renal biopsy.
Alport syndrome is the likely diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in this child is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). It is characterized by the absence of immune deposits on biopsy and histopathological examination. 

It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years).

Biopsy findings of MCD are as follows:

  • Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change')
  • Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome 3 months ago and had been started on a course of oral prednisolone. During the current visit, no improvement is noted with regards to facial puffiness and urine analysis reveals grade 3 proteinuria. Mutations in all of the following are associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. It can be caused due to mutations in the following components of the glomerular filtration barrier:

  • Nephrin, podocin - are molecular components of the slit diaphragm complex
  • Alpha-actinin 4 - is a component of the foot process cytoskeleton

Megalin is not a component of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is present in proximal convoluted tubular cells. Mutations in megalin may lead to some proteinuria but not nephrotic syndrome because glomerular filtration of proteins is not affected.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with sudden onset flank pain and hematuria. Ultrasound reveals enlargement of both kidneys. He is a known case of membranous nephropathy. What is the likely pathophysiology for his current presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in a patient suffering from membranous nephropathy, which is a type of nephrotic syndrome, is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis. It is due to the loss of antithrombin III (an endogenous anticoagulant) in urine.

Renal vein thrombosis is most often a consequence of a hypercoagulable state. In adults, it is most commonly seen in patients with membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: In a patient with  nephrotic syndrome, all of the following are decreased except:
questions.solution:
In nephrotic syndrome, there is an increase in fibrinogen levels.

The following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome:

  • Fibrinogen
  • Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesis

The following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selective proteinuria:

  • Albumin - the largest proportion of protein lost in nephrotic syndrome.
  • Transferrin
  • Cholecalciferol-binding protein
  • Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
  • Ferritin
  • Coagulation factors 
  • Antithrombin III

questions.text: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

Electron microscopy of FSGS shows: 

  • Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes
  • Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells
  • Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.text: Patients diagnosed with which variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are likely to have the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worst prognosis.

There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant - poor prognosis
  • Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified - most common

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image showing deposits in the kidney. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney which is suggestive of membranous nephropathy.

The following electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. It is due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is his renal biopsy findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous nephropathy.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in the adults/elderly. It is a chronic immune-complex-mediated disease. 

The following image of the glomerulus shows the characteristic spikes. The spikes are formed due to the presence of basement membrane material (have affinity to silver stain) in between the immune complex deposits (lack affinity to silver stain).

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with complaints of blood in his urine.  Urine analysis was positive for proteins and red cell casts.  A renal biopsy was done as shown below. Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed granular deposits of C3 on either side of the glomerular basement membrane but was negative for IgG,  C1q, and C4. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferating mesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease. 

The following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangium by immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3.

This condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affects children and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complement pathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinct from it.

In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present, which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activation and consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreased serum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels.

The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called HenochâSchÃ¶nlein purpura. It isÂ a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored urine 2-weeks after recovery from sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. Which of the following statements is false about the given condition?

choices.text: A rapidly progressive form with oliguria develops in 50% of children
It is a form of proliferative glomerulonephritis
Granular IgG and C3 deposits are seen on immunofluorescence
Dome-shaped subepithelial humps are seen on electron microscopy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing hypercellular glomeruli are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Rapidly progressive disease with oliguria is very rare (< 1% of patients). 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It is usually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior.

It usually presents with features of nephritic syndrome including:

  • Hematuria
  • Red cell casts in the urine
  • Azotemia, oliguria
  • Hypertension
  • Mild to moderate proteinuria
  • Edema

On microscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation)
  • Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps 
  • Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane and mesangium

Majority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservative therapy.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show?

choices.text: Proliferating  parietal and visceral epithelial  cells and WBCs in Bowman space
Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
Proliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangium
Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin deposition

questions.solution:
The given image shows aÂ crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) orÂ crescentic glomerulonephritis.

RPGN is a type ofÂ nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and formation of crescents.Â It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with circulatingÂ anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies (ANA).

Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factorsÂ and cytokines in the Bowman space.Â This triggers:

  • Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostlyÂ parietal, but also some visceral cellsÂ 
  • Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblastsÂ 
  • Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin

The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure underwent renal biopsy. It revealed the presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings, and immunofluorescence showing linear, dense, and smooth deposits are suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome.

Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and renal failure. It makes up about 1/5 of cases of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Crescents with linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the glomerular basement membrane are seen on histopathology.

Note: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) causes the pauci-immune type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. There is an absence of immune complex deposition on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: What is the most common manifestation of Alport's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of Alport syndrome is gross or microscopic hematuria, frequently accompanied by red cell casts.

Proteinuria and oliguria may develop later in the disease, and rarely, nephrotic syndrome develops. The deafness may be subtle requiring sensitive testing.

There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy, the glomerular basement membrane shows: 

  • Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning)
  • Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - basket-weave appearance

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It is seen in lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Urinary albumin excretion of how much is considered as microalbuminuria?
questions.solution:
Urinary albumin excretion in the range of 30–300 mg/24 hours is called microalbuminuria. It is the hallmark of early diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions -
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
    • Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis

Option A: In amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.

Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.

Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.

Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:

  • Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.

Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.

Option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells.

Option D: Urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in:
  1. HIV
  2. SLE
  3. CLL
  4. Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.

MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.

The causes of MPGN are as follows:

  • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  • Secondary MPGN
    • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    • α1-antitrypsin deficiency
    • Infections -  hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
    • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis. There are 2 types of MPGN:

  • Type I - It is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes and mesangiocapillary proliferation.
  • Type II - It is now known as dense-deposit disease. It belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies.

Light microscopy findings of MPGN are as follows:

  • Lobular glomeruli with proliferating mesangial cells, capillary endothelium, and infiltrating leukocytes (endocapillary proliferation)
  • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.
